title: If I write a literary work and make a mockery of famous people, could I get sued? - Quora
tags: Legal Issues and Law in Everyday Life

response.answer_text: The good ole libel and slander question. You can google these subjects on your own. I’ll give you 30 seconds or so. Can you get sued? Yes, if your literary work gets noticed by the famous person you can get set up for a slander suit. The real hurdle is your literary work has to become important enough to get noticed. Legally does the suit have “legs”? The real answer is it depends, but the correct answer is probably no. The more famous a person becomes, the more public their lives becomes and at that point the first amendment freedom of expression comes in conflict with a person’s general right to privacy. The more famous the person the lower the privacy expectation and the higher the freedom of expression. See “Our Cartoon President” as an example. It’s clearly about President Trump. It’s clearly an unflattering portrait of the President. However this lampooning is allowed because the president has a much lower expectation of privacy than a normal American. If you were to take the same basic premise and make it about your neighbor, the show would infringe on the person’s basic rights of privacy and a lawsuit would become more viable. I hope this gives you a 30 second answer without me writing a treatise on libel and slander law.

Not a lawyer here. But IMO, people do this all the time. SNL, Robot Chicken, South Park, Family Guy, Stand Up Comedians, etc. They usually have a disclaimer like “any names or likenesses of real people are fictitious” Country laws may vary so check that out. But I think it’s only an issue if you’re leading people to believe that it’s true. These days even that’s getting a pass in many cases.
